title: Lessons from ASIC's fact sheet on SMSFs
text:
If more people establish SMSFs with marginal or no benefit and there is a significant market correction, there is likely to be a regulatory overreaction in the future that could affect all of us.

We should jealously guard the advantages we enjoy in our SMSFs. If barriers to entry are just a little bit higher for new SMSF entrants, then so be it.

The SMSF industry won’t like it from a self-interest perspective, but higher barriers to entry don’t affect existing SMSF investors. We would far prefer voluntary ASIC fact sheets now than a massive future regulatory overreaction.

There are points in ASIC’s fact sheet to take issue with. Let’s call them the bad.

According to ASIC, an average investor dedicates less than two hours a week to running their SMSF. I don’t think this is an unreasonable amount of time to spend funding your dream retirement.

Only ASIC expresses it differently: “It takes over 100 hours a year to run an SMSF.” It could just as easily have written: “It takes over 500 hours every five years to run an SMSF.” The bigger the number, the scarier.

Regardless, if you have an SMSF, expect to spend time self-managing it. The clue is in the name.

ASIC also states that “the average cost of running an SMSF is $13,900 a year". In prior articles, I’ve explained that SMSF averages are incredibly skewed. Because of the fat tail of incredibly large SMSFs, median (middle number) statistics are far more meaningful.

Advertisement

Further, competitive pressures mean you can manage an SMSF for far less than this headline number.

This brings us to the ugly. Unfortunately ASIC’s fact sheet will reignite the bitter war between industry funds and the SMSF sector as everyone twists and contorts it to further their self interests.

In the fact sheet, ASIC compares the pair and determines that generally, SMSFs with balances of less than $500,000 have lower returns.

Industry funds are likely to shout this from the rooftops, ignoring important caveats. But ASIC did include important caveats: “Care must be taken when using SMSF performance figures, particularly when making comparisons. While the methodology used to estimate SMSF performance resembles APRA’s methodology, the data is not the same.”

So everyone (presumably apart from ASIC) must take care before using ASIC comparisons. The data used by ASIC to compare is not the same; there is just a resemblance. Presumably the way apples and oranges resemble each other as round fruit.

Beyond ASIC and the industry funds, the SMSF industry is not immune to hyperbole and overreaction.

It will probably create analysis rejecting each assumption and conclusion made by ASIC. I’m not sure how this benefits you, the SMSF investor. We shout our facts at their facts and confusion reigns.

ASIC has raised some legitimate issues and they don't deserve to be dismissed as part of a dull, statistics methodology debate. With just under $2.9 trillion held in super (of which SMSFs make up $748 billion), there are good public policy reasons to ensure SMSFs are being used for the right reasons.

By 2020, I predict industry funds (which now make up $719 billion) will overtake SMSFs as the largest super sector, but ultimately the power lies with you to decide which super structure is the right one for you.

Tim Mackay is an independent financial adviser at Quantum Financial.
description: Rather than pitting industry funds against DIY options, the regulator's 'nudge' to trustees is a reminder that the power lies with you to decide which structure is the right one for you.
